block.p: Greece to Allow U.S. Force To Have Role at Olympics Greece, under intense pressure from the United States, will allow 400 American Special Forces soldiers to be present at next month's Olympic Games under NATO auspicies and will also permit American, Israeli and possibly British security officers to carry weapons, Greek and American officials said. The arrangements represent a significant departure from Olympic tradition.

Hostage Released in Baghdad A Philippine hostage was released after his government acceded to the hostage-takers' demands and completed the withdrawal of its 51 soldiers and police officers from Iraq. The Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, defended her decision, which drew strong rebukes. In Baquba, north of Baghdad, a roadside bomb killed four Iraqis.

Afghan Refugees Pushed Out The Pakistani Army, backed by United States intelligence and surveillance, has stepped up its operations against supporters of Al Qaeda in the area near the Afghan border in recent weeks, displacing thousands of Afghan refugees.

U.N. Demands Barrier Removal The General Assembly approved a resolution demanding that Israel obey a World Court ruling that it abandon and dismantle its separation barrier on the West Bank and pay compensation to Palestinians affected by its construction.

Pakistan Accused of Abuses Pakistani paramilitary forces have killed at least four Pakistani farmers and tortured dozens of others in a violent dispute with tenant farmers over ownership of fertile land controlled by the Pakistani Army, according to a report to be issued today by an American rights group.

Blair Faces Critics Prime Minister Tony Blair forcefully defended his decision to join America in waging war against Iraq and told Parliament that intelligence assessments left ''little doubt'' that Saddam Hussein was trying to develop prohibited weapons.

Kerry Adviser Quits, Citing Security Inquiry Samuel R. Berger, the former national security adviser to President Bill Clinton, resigned as an adviser to Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign after the disclosure that he improperly removed classified materials on terrorism from a government reading room.

Bush Campaign Plans Attack Seeking to blunt any advantage Senator John Kerry might enjoy from the Democratic convention, President Bush's campaign has planned a monthlong counterattack that will blend criticism of the Democratic ticket with what aides said would be Mr. Bush's first attempt to set out a second-term agenda.

Judicial Nominee Contested Senate Democrats used a filibuster threat to block another of President Bush's judicial candidates, asserting that the nominee, William G. Myers 3rd, a longtime lobbyist for large ranchers and mining interests, is unsuited to be a federal judge.

Black Farmers Assert Bias Black farmers say the Department of Agriculture has failed to make good on the terms of a landmark discrimination settlement, denying restitution to roughly 9 in 10 farmers seeking compensation and spending millions to thwart their claims.

Intelligence Plan Draws Critics Senators questioned whether the installation of a cabinet-level intelligence director would improve the country's intelligence capabilities, giving a cool reception to the idea in its first real test.

States to File Pollution Suit Eight states and New York City plan to sue utilities that they say are the country's biggest emitters of carbon dioxide, the heat-trapping gas that scientists have linked to global warming.
Bush Defends Iraq Actions President Bush told supporters in Iowa that the lessons he learned from Sept. 11, 2001, led him to the decision to depose Saddam Hussein.

Transit Officer Investigated In Subway Pipe Bombing The police investigated whether an off-duty transit officer who reported finding a burning backpack in the Times Square station on Monday night might have placed it there and lighted the pipe bomb inside, several senior police officials said.
Deal on Minimum Wage New York State's two top legislative leaders agreed to gradually raise the minimum wage to $7.15 from $5.15 an hour.

Sunny Report on Subways The Straphangers Campaign issued its annual report card on the state of the subway system, awarding its most positive marks in years, but the transit authority is to release its projected 2005 budget in a week, possibly increasing the price of some MetroCards.

Power Failure Delays Trains A power failure on a stretch of railroad tracks in northern New Jersey played havoc with train service to and from Manhattan, stranding some commuters and delaying hundreds of others.
CBS Leads Ratings With Reruns CBS has increased its ratings lead by showing repeats of a few hit comedies and a modest sprinkling of new reality shows.
Armstrong Takes Lead in France Lance Armstrong won the 16th stage of the Tour de France, taking the overall lead.

Windfall for Microsoft Microsoft announced that it would pay its shareholders $75 billion. The company will issue a one-time cash dividend of $3 a share at a cost of $32 billion. The company also plans to double its quarterly dividend, to 8 cents.
Charles Schwab Fires Chief The Charles Schwab Corporation ousted its chief executive, David S. Pottruck, and said that its chairman and founder, Charles R. Schwab, would return as chief executive.
Greenspan Issues Warning Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned that interest rates could rise more swiftly.

Suit Filed Against Exchange Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, filed a countersuit against the exchange and his successor at the Big Board, contending his contract was breached and his reputation was besmirched.
Editorials: Shrimp and mischief; fleecing American soldiers; chase the guy with the ball; desperadoes.
Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof, William Safire.
